questions.rationale: The treatment regimen for TB often ranges from 26 weeks, but can be up to 2 years, making adherence problematic for many people. The nurse would stress the absolute importance of following the treatment plan for the entire duration of prescribed therapy. The other options are appropriate topics to educate this client on but do not take priority.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem: A client has been admitted for suspected inhalation anthrax infection. What question by the nurse is most important?
options: "Are any family members also ill?"
"Have you traveled recently?"
"How long have you been ill?"
"What is your occupation?"
questions.rationale: Inhalation anthrax is rare and is an occupational hazard among people who work with animal wool, bone meal, hides, and skin, such as taxidermists and veterinarians. Inhalation anthrax seen in someone without an occupational risk is considered a bioterrorism event and must be reported to authorities immediately. The other questions are appropriate for anyone with an infection.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem: A charge nurse is rounding on several older patients on ventilators in the Intensive Care Unit whom the nurse identifies as being at high risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia. To reduce this risk, what activity would the nurse delegate to the assistive personnel (AP)?
options: Encourage between-meal snacks.
Monitor temperature every 4 hours.
Provide oral care every 4 hours.
Report any new onset of cough.
questions.rationale: Oral colonization by gram-negative bacteria is a risk factor for health care-associated pneumonia. Good, frequent oral care can help prevent this from developing and is a task that can be delegated to the AP. Encouraging good nutrition is important, but this will not prevent pneumonia. Monitoring temperature and reporting new cough in patients are important to detect the onset of possible pneumonia but do not prevent it.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem: The emergency department (ED) manager is reviewing client charts to determine how well the staff perform when treating patients with community-acquired pneumonia. What outcome demonstrates that goals for this client type have been met?
options: Antibiotics started before admission.
Blood cultures obtained within 20 minutes.
Chest x-ray obtained within 30 minutes.
Pulse oximetry obtained on all patients.
questions.rationale: Goals for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia include initiating antibiotics prior to inpatient admission or within 6 hours of presentation to the ED. Timely collection of blood cultures, chest x-ray, and pulse oximetry are important as well but do not coincide with established goals.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem: A nurse has educated a client on isoniazid. What statement by the client indicates that teaching has been effective?
options: "I need to take extra vitamin C while on isoniazid."
"I should take this medicine with milk or juice."
"I will take this medication on an empty stomach."
"My contact lenses will be permanently stained."
questions.rationale: Isoniazid needs to be taken on an empty stomach, either 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals. Extra vitamin B needs to be taken while on the drug. Staining of contact lenses commonly occurs while taking rifampin.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem: A client has been taking isoniazid for tuberculosis for 3 weeks. What laboratory results need to be reported to the primary health care provider immediately?
options: Albumin: 5.1 g/dL (7.4 mmol/L)
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 180 U/L
Red blood cell (RBC) count: 5.2/million/µL (5.2 × 10¹²/L)
White blood cell (WBC) count: 12,500/mm³ (12.5 × 10⁹/L)
questions.rationale: INH can cause liver damage, especially if the client drinks alcohol. The ALT (one of the liver enzymes) is extremely high and needs to be reported immediately. The albumin and RBCs are normal. The WBCs are slightly high, but that would be an expected finding in a client with an infection.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem: A client seen in the emergency department reports fever, fatigue, and dry cough but no other upper respiratory symptoms. A chest x-ray reveals mediastinal widening. What action by the nurse is best?
options: Collect a sputum sample for culture by deep suctioning.
Inform the client that oral antibiotics will be needed for 60 days.
Place the client on Airborne Precautions immediately.
Tell the client that directly observed therapy is needed.
questions.rationale: This client has signs and symptoms of early inhalation anthrax. For treatment, after IV antibiotics are finished, oral antibiotics are continued for at least 60 days. Sputum cultures are not needed. Anthrax is not transmissible from person to person, so Standard Precautions are adequate. Directly observed therapy is often used for tuberculosis.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem: A client has been hospitalized with tuberculosis (TB). The client's spouse is fearful of entering the room where the client is in isolation and refuses to visit. What action by the nurse is best?
options: Ask the spouse to explain the fear of visiting in further detail.
Inform the spouse that the precautions are meant to keep other patients safe.
Show the spouse how to follow the Isolation Precautions to avoid illness.
Tell the spouse that he or she has already been exposed, so it's safe to visit.
questions.rationale: The nurse needs to obtain further information about the spouse's specific fears so they can be addressed. This will decrease stress and permit visitation, which will be beneficial for both client and spouse. Precautions for TB prevent transmission to all who come into contact with the client. Explaining Isolation Precautions and what to do when entering the room will be helpful, but this is too narrow in scope to be the best answer. Telling the spouse that it is safe to visit is demeaning of the spouse's feelings.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem: A client is being discharged on long-term therapy for tuberculosis (TB). What referral by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: Community social worker for Meals on Wheels
Occupational therapy for job retraining
Physical therapy for homebound therapy services
Visiting nurses for directly observed therapy
questions.rationale: Directly observed therapy is often utilized for managing patients with TB in the community. Meals on Wheels, job retraining, and home therapy may or may not be appropriate.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem: A client is admitted with suspected pneumonia from the emergency department. The client went to the primary health care provider a "few days ago" and shows the nurse the results of what the client calls an "allergy test," as shown below: [Image shows firm reddened area on arm from skin test]. The reddened area is firm. What action by the nurse is best?
options: Assess the client for possible items to which he or she is allergic.
Call the primary health care provider's office to request records.
Immediately place the client on Airborne Precautions.
Prepare to begin administration of intravenous antibiotics.
questions.rationale: This "allergy test" is actually a positive tuberculosis test. The client would be placed on Airborne Precautions immediately. The other options do not take priority over preventing the spread of the disease.

questions.category: Chapter 25: Concepts of Care for Patients With Infectious Respiratory Conditions
questions.stem:
A nurse admits a client from the emergency department. Client data are listed below: 

History: 70 years of age, History of diabetes, On insulin twice a day, Reports new onset dyspnea and productive cough

Physical Assessment: Crackles and rhonchi heard throughout the lungs, Dullness to percussion LLL, Afebrile, Oriented to person only

Laboratory Values: WBC 5,200/mm³ (5.2 × 10⁹/L), PaO₂ on room air 85 mm Hg

What action by the nurse is the priority?
options: Administer oxygen at 4 L per nasal cannula.
Begin broad-spectrum antibiotics.
Collect a sputum sample for culture.
Start an IV of normal saline at 50 mL/hr.
questions.rationale: All actions are appropriate for this client who has signs and symptoms of pneumonia. However, airway and breathing come first, so begin oxygen administration and titrate it to maintain saturations greater than 95%. Start the IV and collect a sputum culture, and then begin antibiotics.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A nurse answers a call light and finds a client anxious, short of breath, reporting chest pain, and has a blood pressure of 88/52 mm Hg. What action by the nurse takes priority?
options: Assess the client's lung sounds.
Notify the Rapid Response Team.
Provide reassurance to the client.
Take a full set of vital signs.
questions.rationale: This client has signs and symptoms of a pulmonary embolism, and the most critical action is to notify the Rapid Response Team for speedy diagnosis and treatment. The other actions are appropriate also but are not the priority.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client is admitted with a pulmonary embolism (PE). The client is young, healthy, and active and has no known risk factors for PE. What action by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: Encourage the client to walk 5 minutes each hour.
Refer the client to smoking cessation classes.
Teach the client about factor V Leiden testing.
Tell the client that sometimes no cause for disease is found.
questions.rationale: Factor V Leiden is an inherited thrombophilia that can lead to abnormal clotting events, including PE. A client with no known risk factors for this disorder would be asked about family history and referred for testing. Encouraging the client to walk is healthy, but is not related to the development of a PE in this case, nor is smoking. Although there are cases of disease where no cause is ever found, this assumption is premature.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client has a large pulmonary embolism and is started on oxygen. The nurse asks the charge nurse why the client's oxygen saturation has not significantly improved. What response by the nurse is best?
options: "Breathing so rapidly interferes with oxygenation."
"Maybe the client has respiratory distress syndrome."
"The blood clot interferes with perfusion in the lungs."
"The client needs immediate intubation and mechanical ventilation."
questions.rationale: A large blood clot in the lungs will significantly impair gas exchange and oxygenation. Unless the clot is dissolved, this process will continue unabated. Hyperventilation can interfere with oxygenation by shallow breathing, but there is no evidence that the client is hyperventilating. Acute respiratory distress syndrome can occur, but this is not as likely soon after the client starts on oxygen plus there is no indication of how much oxygen the client is on.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client is on intravenous heparin to treat a pulmonary embolism. The client's most recent partial thromboplastin time (PTT) was 25 seconds. What order would the nurse anticipate?
options: Decrease the heparin rate.
Increase the heparin rate.
No change to the heparin rate.
Stop heparin; start warfarin.
questions.rationale: For Patients on heparin, a PTT of 1.5 to 2.5 times the normal value is needed to demonstrate that the heparin is working. A normal PTT is 25 to 35 seconds, so this client's PTT value is too low. The heparin rate needs to be increased. Warfarin is not indicated in this situation.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client is hospitalized with a second episode of pulmonary embolism (PE). Recent genetic testing reveals that the client has an alteration in the gene CYP2C19. What action by the nurse is best?
options: Instruct the client to eliminate all vitamin K from the diet.
Prepare preoperative teaching for an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter.
Refer the client to a chronic illness support group.
Teach the client to use a soft-bristled toothbrush.
questions.rationale: Often Patients are discharged from the hospital on warfarin after a PE. However, Patients with a variation in the CYP2C19 gene do not metabolize warfarin well and have much higher blood levels and more side effects. This client is a poor candidate for warfarin therapy, and the prescriber will most likely order an IVC filter device to be implanted.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A nurse is caring for four Patients on intravenous heparin therapy. Which laboratory value possibly indicates that a serious side effect has occurred?
options: Hemoglobin: 14.2 g/dL (142 g/L)
Platelet count: 82,000/L (82 × 10⁹/L)
Red blood cell count: 4.8/mm³ (4.8 × 10¹²/L)
White blood cell count: 8700/mm³ (8.7 × 10⁹/L)
questions.rationale: This platelet count is low and could indicate heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. The other values are normal for either gender.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client in the intensive care unit (ICU) is mechanically ventilated and has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). What assessment finding would be most concerning to the nurse?
options: Respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute
Oxygen saturation of 88% on 100% oxygen
Blood pressure of 92/58 mm Hg
Heart rate of 92 beats per minute
questions.rationale: A low oxygen saturation despite high oxygen delivery in ARDS indicates severe ventilation-perfusion mismatch and is the most concerning finding. This indicates disease progression and the need for advanced interventions such as prone positioning or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). The other values are relatively stable.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has a PaO2 of 55 mm Hg and is on a ventilator with 100% oxygen. The nurse anticipates which intervention?
options: Increase the ventilator tidal volume.
Initiate prone positioning protocol.
Reduce the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).
Sedate the client for paralysis.
questions.rationale: Prone positioning can improve oxygenation in ARDS by redistributing blood flow to better-ventilated areas of the lungs and opening atelectatic areas in the dependent portions of the lungs. A PaO2 of 55 is severely hypoxemic despite maximum oxygen therapy. Increasing tidal volumes can cause barotrauma. Reducing PEEP would further worsen oxygenation. Paralysis is considered after other measures.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client is experiencing severe acute respiratory failure. Which ABG result would indicate the need for immediate mechanical ventilation?
options: pH 7.35, PaCO2 45 mm Hg, HCO3 24 mEq/L
pH 7.25, PaCO2 65 mm Hg, HCO3 24 mEq/L
pH 7.45, PaCO2 35 mm Hg, HCO3 24 mEq/L
pH 7.40, PaCO2 40 mm Hg, HCO3 24 mEq/L
questions.rationale: This ABG shows respiratory acidosis with a very high PaCO2 (65 mm Hg), indicating severe hypoventilation and inadequate gas exchange. The client needs mechanical ventilation to support ventilation and restore normal CO2 levels. The other ABGs are within normal or compensated ranges.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client who suffered a traumatic pneumothorax is being treated with a chest tube and water-seal drainage. What finding would indicate an air leak in the system?
options: Fluctuation in the water-seal chamber with each breath
Continuous bubbling in the water-seal chamber
Absence of fluctuation in the water-seal chamber
Bloody drainage collecting in the drainage chamber
questions.rationale: Continuous bubbling in the water-seal chamber indicates an air leak in the system, which can allow air to enter the pleural space. Fluctuation (tidaling) with breathing is normal. Absence of fluctuation may indicate the lung has re-expanded or there is a clot in the tube. Bloody drainage is expected with traumatic pneumothorax but does not indicate an air leak.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client with a tension pneumothorax arrives at the emergency department in severe distress. Before a chest tube can be placed, what action by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: Administer oxygen at high flow rates.
Place the client in Trendelenburg position.
Prepare for needle decompression.
Wait for radiology confirmation with an X-ray.
questions.rationale: Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening emergency that causes cardiovascular collapse. It requires immediate needle decompression (needle thoracostomy) in the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line. This converts the tension pneumothorax to a simple pneumothorax and restores circulation. Waiting for X-ray confirmation would be fatal. After decompression, a chest tube is placed.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client with a flail chest from multiple rib fractures is experiencing severe pain with breathing. What nursing intervention would be most effective for pain management?
options: Withhold pain medication to monitor breathing patterns.
Apply firm strapping or taping across the rib cage.
Provide adequate analgesia to allow effective breathing and coughing.
Place the client on bedrest with no position changes.
questions.rationale: With flail chest, adequate pain control is essential because pain causes splinting (shallow breathing) that leads to hypoxia and pneumonia. Analgesia allows the client to breathe deeply, cough effectively, and mobilize secretions. Strapping or taping is contraindicated as it restricts movement and increases pneumonia risk. The client should be encouraged to move and ambulate. Withholding pain medication is unsafe.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client is recovering from acute epiglottitis with stridor. Which nursing action is essential for client safety?
options: Examine the throat with a tongue depressor to visualize the epiglottis.
Have emergency intubation equipment available at the bedside.
Encourage the client to lie flat to ease breathing.
Apply a cool mist humidifier and reassure the client.
questions.rationale: A client with acute epiglottitis is at high risk for complete airway obstruction. Emergency equipment including intubation supplies must be immediately available. Examining the throat with a tongue depressor is contraindicated as it can trigger complete airway obstruction. The client should sit upright or semi-upright. Cool mist may help but equipment availability is the priority.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client with massive pulmonary embolism is experiencing acute cardiovascular collapse. What medication would the nurse anticipate for immediate administration?
options: Oral warfarin for anticoagulation
Intravenous alteplase (tPA) for thrombolysis
Subcutaneous enoxaparin for anticoagulation
Intravenous morphine for pain and anxiety
questions.rationale: In massive PE with cardiovascular collapse, fibrinolytic therapy (thrombolysis) with tPA is the only intervention that can rapidly dissolve the clot. Anticoagulants are too slow. This is a life-threatening emergency requiring aggressive treatment. Morphine can be used but is not the priority treatment.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client on mechanical ventilation is being weaned by gradually decreasing the ventilator support. What assessment finding would indicate that weaning should be stopped and the client returned to full ventilator support?
options: Respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute
Oxygen saturation of 92% on current settings
Heart rate of 88 beats per minute
Systolic blood pressure of 110 mm Hg
questions.rationale: A respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute indicates increased work of breathing and respiratory muscle fatigue during weaning. This signals that the client is not ready to continue weaning and should be returned to full support. Successful weaning parameters include respiratory rate less than 25, oxygen saturation greater than 92%, stable heart rate and blood pressure.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client with severe respiratory failure from COVID-19 has been on a mechanical ventilator for 2 weeks. The client is sedated and paralyzed. What complication should the nurse monitor for most closely?
options: Hyperglycemia from stress response
Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
Acute kidney injury from sepsis
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
questions.rationale: Ventilator-associated pneumonia is one of the most common and serious complications of prolonged mechanical ventilation. Sedated and paralyzed clients cannot cough, and aspiration risk increases. VAP significantly increases mortality. Prevention measures include elevating the head of bed, oral care, and avoiding unnecessary sedation. The other complications can occur but VAP is most directly related to ventilation status.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client recovering from acute respiratory failure is extubated successfully. What is the priority nursing intervention in the immediate post-extubation period?
options: Advance the client's diet to regular food.
Monitor closely for signs of respiratory distress and stridor.
Perform vigorous chest physiotherapy.
Remove all oxygen delivery devices and monitor for self-ventilation.
questions.rationale: After extubation, close monitoring for respiratory distress, stridor, or other signs of airway compromise is critical. The client may require rapid reintubation if problems develop. Stridor may indicate upper airway edema and requires immediate attention. Diet can be advanced gradually based on ability to swallow. Oxygen support is typically continued after extubation.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client with pulmonary hypertension is prescribed a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor. What education should the nurse provide about this medication?
options: The medication will cure the pulmonary hypertension.
Chest pain will improve within 24 hours of starting the medication.
The medication helps relax pulmonary vessels to reduce heart strain.
The medication should be taken with grapefruit juice for better absorption.
questions.rationale: Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (like sildenafil) cause vasodilation of pulmonary vessels, reducing pulmonary hypertension and decreasing right heart workload. Pulmonary hypertension cannot be cured; management is lifelong. Improvement takes time. Grapefruit juice inhibits metabolism and increases drug levels dangerously.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is on positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 15 cm H2O. The nurse notices the client's blood pressure has dropped from 140/80 to 90/50 mm Hg. What is the most likely cause?
options: Sepsis from hospital-acquired infection
Decreased venous return due to high intrathoracic pressure
Pulmonary embolism
Myocardial infarction
questions.rationale: High PEEP increases intrathoracic pressure, which can impede venous return to the heart, decreasing cardiac output and causing hypotension. This is a known adverse effect of PEEP. The nurse should notify the provider to consider reducing PEEP or providing fluid resuscitation. The timing with PEEP increase and the BP drop together point to this cause.

questions.category: Chapter 26: Critical Care of Patients With Respiratory Emergencies
questions.stem: A client with a history of smoking is experiencing shortness of breath and has a productive cough with pink, frothy sputum. What condition does the nurse most likely suspect?
options: Pneumonia with sepsis
Acute pulmonary edema from left heart failure
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation
Pulmonary embolism
questions.rationale: Pink, frothy sputum is classic for pulmonary edema, indicating fluid leaking from pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli. This occurs with left heart failure or acute coronary syndromes. The client presents with classic signs: dyspnea, cough, and characteristic sputum. Pneumonia would produce yellow or green sputum. COPD and PE don't typically produce pink, frothy sputum.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A nurse is performing a cardiovascular assessment on a client. When palpating the apical pulse, the nurse locates the point of maximal impulse (PMI). At which anatomical location should the nurse expect to find the PMI?
options: Second intercostal space at the left midclavicular line
Fifth intercostal space at the left midclavicular line
Fifth intercostal space at the left anterior axillary line
Fourth intercostal space at the right midclavicular line
questions.rationale: The PMI is normally located at the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line (also called the midsternal line). This corresponds to the apex of the left ventricle. In obese clients or those with chest wall abnormalities, the PMI may be difficult to palpate but should still be in this location.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: During a cardiovascular assessment, the nurse hears a murmur. To best characterize the murmur, which aspects should the nurse evaluate? (Select all that apply.)
options: Timing in the cardiac cycle
Location on the chest wall
Radiation of the murmur
Intensity and pitch
Respiratory variation
questions.rationale: A complete murmur assessment includes when it occurs in the cardiac cycle (systolic vs. diastolic), where it is best heard, whether it radiates, and its intensity (grade 1-6) and pitch. Some murmurs vary with respiration, but not all, so respiratory variation is assessed but not universally present.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A nurse assesses a client and notes a pulse deficit. What does a pulse deficit indicate?
options: The systolic blood pressure is higher than normal.
The apical pulse rate is faster than the radial pulse rate.
The client has an irregular heart rhythm.
The client has hypertension with a widened pulse pressure.
questions.rationale: A pulse deficit occurs when the apical pulse is greater than the peripheral pulse (usually radial). This indicates that some cardiac contractions are not strong enough to create a palpable peripheral pulse. This occurs with irregular heart rhythms and arrhythmias, most commonly atrial fibrillation.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client has significant peripheral edema in both lower extremities. The nurse assesses the edema as "3+" on a 4-point scale. What does this indicate?
options: Slight pitting edema that disappears immediately when pressure is released
Moderate pitting edema that returns to baseline within 15 seconds
Deep pitting edema that returns to baseline within 1-2 minutes
Non-pitting edema that does not return to baseline
questions.rationale: On the 4-point pitting edema scale: 1+ is slight (disappears immediately), 2+ is mild (returns within 15 seconds), 3+ is moderate (returns within 1-2 minutes), and 4+ is severe (lasts more than 2 minutes). Grading 3+ indicates significant fluid retention.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client has elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP). What does this assessment finding most likely indicate?
options: Left ventricular hypertrophy
Right-sided heart failure
Aortic valve stenosis
Mitral valve regurgitation
questions.rationale: Elevated JVP indicates increased right atrial pressure, which occurs with right-sided heart failure or conditions causing right ventricular dysfunction. JVP is measured with the client in a 45-degree position, and elevation suggests backup of blood into the systemic venous system.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A nurse observes a client's carotid pulses and notes that they are bounding and rapidly rising and falling. What pathological condition is most consistent with this finding?
options: Aortic stenosis
Aortic regurgitation
Mitral stenosis
Pulmonary hypertension
questions.rationale: A bounding, rapidly rising and falling carotid pulse (water-hammer or collapsing pulse) is characteristic of aortic regurgitation. The rapid rise occurs as blood is ejected forcefully into the aorta; the rapid fall occurs as blood regurgitates backward into the left ventricle. This produces the distinctive "bounding" quality.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A nurse is teaching a client how to assess radial pulses at home. What instructions should the nurse provide? (Select all that apply.)
options: Use the thumb to palpate the client's own radial pulse
Apply firm pressure over the radial artery on the lateral wrist
Count the pulse for a full 60 seconds
Note the rhythm and regularity of the pulse
Document the strength of the pulse using a 0-4+ scale
questions.rationale: Correct technique includes using fingers (not the thumb, which has its own pulse), applying moderate pressure on the radial artery, counting for at least 60 seconds (especially if irregular), assessing rhythm, and grading the strength. All of these are appropriate for home pulse assessment.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client undergoing cardiac catheterization develops chest discomfort during the procedure. The electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation. What action by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: Notify the cardiologist immediately, as this suggests acute myocardial infarction.
Reassure the client that some discomfort is expected during the procedure.
Administer IV nitroglycerin as previously ordered.
Continue monitoring and document the finding in the patient record.
questions.rationale: ST-segment elevation during cardiac catheterization is an emergency finding that indicates acute coronary occlusion and myocardial infarction. The cardiologist must be notified immediately for emergency intervention such as angioplasty or stent placement. This is not a normal finding and requires immediate action.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A nurse assesses a client recovering from cardiac catheterization via the right femoral artery. What assessment is most critical in the first few hours after the procedure?
options: Auscultation of lung sounds
Assessment of the catheter insertion site and distal leg perfusion
Palpation of the abdomen for tenderness
Evaluation of cardiac murmurs
questions.rationale: After femoral artery cardiac catheterization, the most critical assessment is checking the insertion site for bleeding or hematoma formation and evaluating distal leg perfusion (including pulse, temperature, color, and sensation). Vascular complications such as pseudoaneurysm or thrombosis can develop and compromise limb perfusion.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client is referred for a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). Before the procedure, the nurse provides education. What important information should be included?
options: The client will be awake but sedated during the procedure.
The throat will be sprayed with a topical anesthetic.
The gag reflex may be diminished during and after the procedure.
NPO status is required before the procedure.
questions.rationale: TEE education includes explaining sedation (client is sedated but responsive), topical anesthesia to the throat, risk of diminished gag reflex (caution with eating/drinking afterward), and NPO status to prevent aspiration. The client should not have anything to eat or drink for 4-6 hours before the procedure.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client is referred for a stress test. Before the test, the nurse asks which medications the client should discontinue. Which medication would the nurse expect the provider to ask the client to hold before a stress test?
options: Acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin)
Beta-blockers such as metoprolol
Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
Calcium channel blockers
questions.rationale: Beta-blockers blunt the heart's response to exercise and can produce false-negative stress test results by preventing the heart rate from rising adequately. They are typically held 24-48 hours before stress testing. Aspirin and ACE inhibitors don't significantly affect the test. Calcium channel blockers may be held but are less critical.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A nurse reviews a client's cardiac assessment findings. The nurse documents: "S1 normal; physiologic S3 present." Which situation would be most consistent with this finding?
options: An 80-year-old client with a history of myocardial infarction
A 25-year-old athletic client with no history of cardiac disease
A 60-year-old client with aortic stenosis
A 70-year-old client with aortic regurgitation
questions.rationale: A physiologic S3 (ventricular gallop) can be a normal finding in young, athletic individuals and children due to rapid ventricular filling. In older adults (over 40), S3 typically indicates pathology such as heart failure, mitral regurgitation, or cardiomyopathy and is called a pathologic S3.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client has a history of rheumatic heart disease. Which heart sound finding would the nurse most likely assess?
options: A systolic ejection murmur at the right second intercostal space
A diastolic rumble at the apex with an opening snap
A continuous "machinery" murmur
An early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border
questions.rationale: Rheumatic heart disease most commonly causes mitral stenosis. The characteristic finding is a diastolic rumble (low-pitched, heard best at the apex with the client in the left lateral position) with an opening snap at the beginning of diastole. This reflects narrowing of the mitral valve.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client is being evaluated for heart failure. The nurse obtains vital signs and notes: blood pressure 158/94 mm Hg, heart rate 102 beats per minute, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute. What additional assessment would help confirm left ventricular dysfunction?
options: Presence of crackles in the lungs
Absence of peripheral edema
Clear neck veins with normal JVP
Normal S1 and S2 without murmurs
questions.rationale: Crackles (rales) indicate pulmonary edema, which occurs when left ventricular dysfunction causes increased pulmonary venous pressure. The combination of elevated vital signs, tachycardia, tachypnea, and crackles strongly suggests acute left heart failure. The other findings would not support this diagnosis.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client presenting with an acute coronary syndrome is being evaluated for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). What information should the nurse verify before the client goes to the catheterization laboratory?
options: Allergy history, especially to contrast dye and iodine
Baseline creatinine level to assess renal function
NPO status since midnight
Presence of arterial and venous access lines
questions.rationale: Before PCI, critical information includes allergy history (especially iodine/shellfish/contrast sensitivity), baseline renal function (contrast can cause kidney injury), NPO status, and informed consent. Arterial access is typically established during the procedure, not before.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A nurse is caring for a client after a cardiovascular event and notes changes in the client's level of consciousness and orientation. Which laboratory value would be most important for the nurse to assess to evaluate cerebral perfusion?
options: Hemoglobin and hematocrit
Cardiac output and systemic vascular resistance
Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level
Troponin and creatinine kinase levels
questions.rationale: Cardiac output and systemic vascular resistance determine tissue perfusion, including cerebral perfusion. Changes in consciousness can indicate inadequate cerebral perfusion from decreased cardiac output or excessive vasodilation. Hemoglobin affects oxygen-carrying capacity but not perfusion directly. BNP and cardiac enzymes indicate heart damage but not current perfusion status.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client has been on cardiac monitoring for 24 hours. The nurse reviews the rhythm strips and notes occasional premature atrial contractions (PACs). What should the nurse do?
options: Notify the provider immediately as PACs indicate the need for medication.
Continue monitoring and inform the provider unless PACs become frequent or symptomatic.
Administer prescribed antiarrhythmic medication immediately.
Prepare for emergency cardioversion.
questions.rationale: Occasional PACs are common and often benign, especially in stressed or hospitalized patients. Monitoring continues and the provider is informed for documentation, but treatment is usually not needed unless PACs become frequent (>6 per minute), occur in pairs or clusters, or the client develops symptoms. Emergency measures are not warranted for PACs.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client undergoing a 6-minute walk test during cardiac evaluation stops early because of shortness of breath and chest discomfort. The nurse observes that the client is pale and diaphoretic. What action is most appropriate?
options: Encourage the client to continue walking to complete the test.
Stop the test immediately and assess the client's vital signs and EKG.
Give the client a few minutes to rest, then resume the test.
Document that the client could not tolerate the activity and discharge.
questions.rationale: A client reporting chest discomfort and shortness of breath with objective signs of distress (pallor, diaphoresis) requires immediate termination of the stress test and thorough evaluation. These are warning signs of acute cardiac ischemia or other serious conditions. EKG and vital signs must be obtained immediately.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A client has been diagnosed with hypertension and is being educated about home blood pressure monitoring. Which technique would the nurse identify as incorrect?
options: Measure blood pressure at the same time each day.
Take measurements in the morning before eating.
Sit with feet flat on the floor and back supported.
Place the cuff over clothing to reduce discomfort.
questions.rationale: The blood pressure cuff must be placed directly on the skin (usually at the arm at heart level), not over clothing, as clothing can affect the accuracy of the reading. Proper technique includes consistent timing, NPO status, proper positioning with feet flat and back supported, and empty bladder.

questions.category: Chapter 27: Assessment of the Cardiovascular System
questions.stem: A nurse assesses a client with new-onset atrial fibrillation presenting with a rapid ventricular response. What priority assessment should the nurse perform?
options: Obtain a 12-lead EKG to confirm the rhythm.
Assess for signs and symptoms of inadequate tissue perfusion.
Check troponin levels to rule out myocardial infarction.
Obtain a history of prior episodes of atrial fibrillation.
questions.rationale: With rapid ventricular response (heart rate often >100 bpm), atrial fibrillation causes loss of the atrial kick and decreased cardiac output. Priority assessment is checking for signs of inadequate perfusion: hypotension, altered mental status, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, or poor perfusion. The EKG confirms the rhythm but assessment of the client's condition is more urgent.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client in the cardiac unit is monitored and shows a rhythm with a heart rate of 140 bpm, narrow QRS complex, and regular rhythm. The client reports palpitations and mild chest discomfort. What is the most likely dysrhythmia?
options: Atrial flutter
Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)
Ventricular tachycardia (VT)
Atrial fibrillation
questions.rationale: SVT presents with a regular narrow-complex tachycardia (HR >150 bpm), normal QRS, and often no visible P waves as they are buried in the T wave. Symptoms include palpitations and chest discomfort. Atrial flutter typically has a slower ventricular rate with flutter waves visible. VT has wide QRS complexes. A-fib is irregular.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is in acute distress. Before attempting vagal maneuvers, what medication might the provider order for rapid conversion?
options: Intravenous digoxin loading dose
Intravenous adenosine rapid bolus
Intravenous calcium channel blocker
Intravenous amiodarone infusion
questions.rationale: Intravenous adenosine is the first-line medication for acute SVT conversion. It works by blocking AV node conduction and has a very short half-life (seconds). Vagal maneuvers (Valsalva, carotid massage) can be tried first if the client is stable. Digoxin works but is slower. Calcium channel blockers and amiodarone are alternatives if adenosine fails.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with atrial flutter has a ventricular rate of 120 bpm. What EKG finding characterizes atrial flutter?
options: Irregular rhythm with no visible P waves
Sawtooth pattern of atrial activity with a regular ventricular rate
Wide QRS complexes with prolonged PR intervals
Chaotic baseline with absent P waves and irregular rhythm
questions.rationale: Atrial flutter is characterized by a regular sawtooth or "flutter" wave pattern in place of normal P waves. These flutter waves occur at a rate of 250-350 atrial contractions per minute. The ventricular response is typically regular (unlike atrial fibrillation) and depends on the degree of AV block.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with new-onset atrial fibrillation has a ventricular response rate of 165 bpm. Which clinical finding would be most concerning to the nurse?
options: Irregular pulse with no peripheral edema
Hypotension with altered mental status
Mild dyspnea during exertion
Occasional palpitations with normal blood pressure
questions.rationale: A rapid ventricular response (165 bpm) with hypotension and altered mental status indicates hemodynamic compromise. The client may need emergent cardioversion. Rapid A-fib decreases cardiac output due to loss of atrial kick and inadequate ventricular filling. This is a medical emergency.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client has had atrial fibrillation for 3 months and is being treated with warfarin and a rate-control medication. What is the primary reason for anticoagulation in this client?
options: To prevent bleeding complications from the rhythm disturbance
To reduce the risk of thromboembolic stroke
To slow the ventricular response rate
To convert atrial fibrillation to normal sinus rhythm
questions.rationale: In atrial fibrillation, the irregular atrial contractions lead to blood stasis in the atria, particularly in the left atrial appendage. This significantly increases the risk of thrombus formation and thromboembolic stroke. Anticoagulation therapy prevents clot formation. Rate control and rhythm control are separate treatment goals.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client on amiodarone for atrial fibrillation should be monitored for which serious adverse effect?
options: Hyperkalemia and muscle weakness
Pulmonary fibrosis and thyroid dysfunction
Hypoglycemia and weight loss
Renal failure and electrolyte imbalance
questions.rationale: Amiodarone is a potent antiarrhythmic with significant adverse effects. Pulmonary fibrosis (which can be irreversible and life-threatening) and thyroid dysfunction (hypo- or hyperthyroidism) are serious concerns requiring baseline and periodic monitoring including chest X-ray, PFTs, and thyroid function tests.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A monitor technician alerts the nurse to a client's monitor strip showing a regular rhythm at 42 bpm with a prolonged PR interval and occasional dropped QRS complexes. What type of heart block is this?
options: First-degree AV block
Second-degree AV block Type I (Wenckebach)
Second-degree AV block Type II
Complete heart block (Third-degree AV block)
questions.rationale: Second-degree AV block Type II presents with a normal or prolonged PR interval followed by a dropped QRS complex (P wave without QRS). Unlike Type I (Wenckebach) where the PR interval progressively lengthens before a dropped beat, Type II shows a constant PR interval with occasional dropped complexes. A bradycardia of 42 bpm is consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with Mobitz II (second-degree AV block Type II) is experiencing syncope and fatigue. The nurse anticipates which intervention?
options: Administration of atropine to increase heart rate
Pacemaker insertion
Strict bed rest and observation
Increased sodium intake to stabilize conduction
questions.rationale: Mobitz II is a serious arrhythmia with high risk of progression to complete heart block. Symptomatic patients (syncope, fatigue) with Mobitz II typically require permanent pacemaker placement. Atropine is ineffective and bed rest is not a solution. This is different from Mobitz I (Wenckebach), which is usually benign.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client in the coronary care unit develops a wide-complex tachycardia at a rate of 160 bpm. The client is alert and hemodynamically stable. What is the most appropriate first intervention?
options: Perform synchronized cardioversion immediately.
Administer intravenous amiodarone per protocol.
Check the client and monitor for any changes.
Initiate a dopamine infusion for blood pressure support.
questions.rationale: In a hemodynamically stable client with wide-complex tachycardia, the first step is to confirm the rhythm and check the client's clinical status. While the rhythm may be concerning, the client is stable, so cardioversion is not immediately indicated. Medication (amiodarone) might be considered after confirming the rhythm and assessing the client. Close observation is appropriate.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with ventricular tachycardia is in cardiac arrest and unresponsive. After initiating CPR and activating the code team, what medication should the nurse anticipate for administration?
options: Intravenous adenosine rapid bolus
Intravenous epinephrine or vasopressin per ACLS protocol
Intravenous amiodarone or lidocaine per ACLS protocol
Intravenous atropine for bradycardia support
questions.rationale: In cardiac arrest with VT/VF, ACLS protocols call for epinephrine (or vasopressin, less common now) given every 3-5 minutes and amiodarone (or lidocaine if amiodarone unavailable) given after the first or second defibrillation attempt. Adenosine is not used in cardiac arrest. Atropine is for bradycardias.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with a newly implanted permanent pacemaker is being discharged home. What important safety instruction should the nurse provide?
options: Avoid all electrical devices and appliances.
Avoid certain security systems, metal detectors, and powerful magnets.
Never use a microwave oven or cell phone.
Keep the pacemaker magnet away from the pacemaker at all times.
questions.rationale: Clients with pacemakers should avoid intense magnetic fields (MRI machines without special pacemaker settings), security gate metal detectors, and certain security systems. Modern pacemakers are resistant to most household appliances, microwave ovens, and cell phones. A magnet can be used in emergency to temporarily disable the pacemaker if needed.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with a permanent pacemaker begins experiencing dizziness and palpitations. The client reports the symptoms started 3 weeks after pacemaker implantation. What complication might the nurse suspect?
options: Pacemaker syndrome (loss of AV synchrony)
Electromagnetic interference from household appliances
Battery depletion of the pacemaker
Infection at the pacemaker insertion site
questions.rationale: Pacemaker syndrome occurs when the pacemaker paces the ventricles without AV synchrony, causing symptoms like dizziness, palpitations, and dyspnea, usually weeks to months after implantation. This can be resolved by programming the pacemaker to maintain AV synchrony. Battery depletion takes years. Infection would present with other signs.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client is scheduled for an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement. What primary indication for an ICD should the nurse understand?
options: Frequent premature atrial contractions with symptoms
History of recurrent life-threatening ventricular dysrhythmias
Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
Complete heart block unresponsive to pacemaker therapy
questions.rationale: ICDs are indicated for clients with recurrent, life-threatening ventricular dysrhythmias (VT/VF) or for primary prevention in high-risk individuals. The device can pace like a pacemaker but also delivers an electrical shock to terminate dangerous rhythms. PACs, A-fib, and complete heart block are treated with pacemakers or medications, not ICDs.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with long QT syndrome is being educated about preventing dysrhythmias. Which medication should the nurse instruct the client to avoid?
options: Acetaminophen for pain relief
Certain antibiotics and antifungal agents
Aspirin for cardiovascular protection
Ibuprofen for fever reduction
questions.rationale: Certain medications (some antibiotics like macrolides and fluoroquinolones, antifungals, antipsychotics, and some antiarrhythmics) prolong the QT interval and can trigger torsades de pointes in susceptible clients. The client should maintain a medication list and discuss all medications with providers.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client develops premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) during hospitalization. Which finding would be most concerning to the nurse?
options: Occasional isolated PVCs occurring every 5-10 minutes
Multiple unifocal PVCs occurring in pairs
PVCs occurring every 20-30 minutes in a client post-MI
One PVC followed by two normal beats (trigeminy pattern)
questions.rationale: Multiple PVCs occurring in pairs (couplets) or runs suggest increased irritability and risk of progression to ventricular tachycardia. Multiform (multifocal) PVCs from different sites are especially concerning. Occasional isolated PVCs are common and usually benign. PVCs in post-MI clients should be monitored but isolated PVCs are less concerning than couplets.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with sick sinus syndrome experiences periods of profound bradycardia alternating with bouts of tachycardia. What treatment is most appropriate?
options: Beta-blocker therapy to control tachycardia
Permanent dual-chamber pacemaker placement
Antiarrhythmic medication with rate-control agents
Cardioversion for the tachycardic episodes
questions.rationale: Sick sinus syndrome with symptomatic bradycardia-tachycardia requires pacemaker therapy, typically a dual-chamber device. A pacemaker provides pacing for bradycardia while medications (beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers) control the tachycardia. A pacemaker alone doesn't treat tachycardia, so a combination approach is needed.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client taking digoxin for atrial fibrillation rate control is experiencing nausea, vomiting, and visual changes. What action by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: Administer an antiemetic and continue the digoxin as scheduled.
Hold the digoxin dose and notify the provider for a serum digoxin level.
Reduce the digoxin dose by half without notifying the provider.
Encourage the client to eat more food before taking the digoxin.
questions.rationale: These are classic signs of digoxin toxicity. The digoxin should be held and the provider notified for serum digoxin level assessment and potential dose adjustment. Digoxin has a narrow therapeutic index (0.5-2.0 ng/mL), and toxicity can cause arrhythmias and other serious effects. Never reduce medication without provider order.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client presenting to the emergency department with palpitations is found to have a regular narrow-complex tachycardia at 190 bpm. The client is conscious and hemodynamically stable. What is the first intervention the nurse should prepare for?
options: Synchronized cardioversion
Intravenous adenosine bolus
Intravenous amiodarone infusion
Valsalva maneuver or carotid massage
questions.rationale: In a hemodynamically stable client with SVT, non-pharmacologic vagal maneuvers (Valsalva, carotid massage) are attempted first. If unsuccessful, adenosine is the next step. Cardioversion is reserved for hemodynamically unstable clients. Amiodarone is slower acting and used for other rhythms.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation reports frequent episodes triggered by caffeine and stress. What teaching would be most effective?
options: Eliminate all caffeine from the diet permanently.
Identify and avoid known triggers; include stress management techniques.
Take prophylactic antiarrhythmic medication before stressful events.
Avoid all physical activity that increases heart rate.
questions.rationale: For paroxysmal A-fib, identifying and avoiding triggers (caffeine, stress, sleep deprivation, alcohol) is an important management strategy. Stress management including relaxation techniques, exercise (not complete avoidance), and sleep hygiene can reduce episodes. Prophylactic medication may be used but trigger avoidance is the foundation.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Concepts of Care for Patients With Dysrhythmias
questions.stem: A client with a history of atrial fibrillation is presenting with syncope, shortness of breath, and a heart rate of 180 bpm. The client is pale and diaphoretic. What is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
options: Administer sublingual nitroglycerin.
Prepare for synchronized cardioversion.
Start an IV and administer adenosine.
Place the client on continuous cardiac monitoring and observe.
questions.rationale: This client is hemodynamically unstable (syncope, severe symptoms, and objective signs of distress). Synchronized cardioversion is indicated for unstable clients with symptomatic tachycardias. The client requires immediate electrical therapy to restore perfusion. Medications are too slow when the client is unstable.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client is admitted with acute myocardial infarction and is having chest pain unrelieved by rest or sublingual nitroglycerin. What action by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: Administer intramuscular morphine.
Notify the provider immediately for intravenous morphine and possible emergent intervention.
Apply a heating pad to the chest.
Encourage the client to cough and deep breathe to relieve pain.
questions.rationale: Unrelieved chest pain in acute MI is a medical emergency requiring immediate provider notification. IV morphine is indicated for pain control and its vasodilatory effects reduce cardiac workload. The client may need emergent reperfusion therapy (PCI or thrombolytics). IM injections are avoided in MI (muscle injury). Heat and coughing are not appropriate.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client 3 days post-myocardial infarction is being prepared for cardiac rehabilitation. Which type of activity would be most appropriate to begin with?
options: Walking 1-2 miles daily at a brisk pace
Resistive exercises with weights
Light activity with gradual progression such as walking in the halls
Competitive sports or heavy labor
questions.rationale: Cardiac rehabilitation is progressive. In the acute phase (days 3-5 post-MI), light activity such as supervised walking in halls is appropriate. Activity is gradually increased based on the client's tolerance and medical stability. Heavy exertion, competitive activities, and resistance training come later in rehabilitation.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client is diagnosed with acute decompensated heart failure (acute HF) and presents with orthopnea, crackles in lungs, elevated JVP, and peripheral edema. What is the primary goal of initial treatment?
options: Increase cardiac contractility with inotropic agents.
Reduce preload and improve oxygenation with diuretics and vasodilators.
Restrict all sodium and fluid intake completely.
Promote sodium retention to expand intravascular volume.
questions.rationale: In acute HF, the primary goal is to reduce pulmonary congestion (orthopnea, crackles) and peripheral edema by reducing preload. Diuretics decrease fluid volume, and vasodilators reduce afterload and preload. Improving oxygenation and reducing workload on the heart are essential. Sodium and fluid should be restricted, but not completely. Inotropes are reserved for cardiogenic shock.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with chronic systolic heart failure is prescribed an ACE inhibitor. How does this medication benefit the client?
options: It increases heart rate to improve cardiac output.
It decreases afterload and prevents ventricular remodeling.
It promotes sodium retention to maintain blood volume.
It increases fluid retention to support kidneys.
questions.rationale: ACE inhibitors block angiotensin II formation, which reduces afterload (decreases systemic vascular resistance), improves cardiac output, and prevents the remodeling process that leads to heart failure progression. They also have neurohormonal benefits. They don't increase heart rate or promote fluid retention.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with aortic stenosis is experiencing chest pain and syncope with exertion. Why is this combination of symptoms particularly concerning?
options: The client is at high risk for sudden cardiac death during exertion.
The symptoms will eventually resolve without treatment.
The client should increase physical activity to strengthen the heart.
These symptoms indicate anxiety rather than cardiac disease.
questions.rationale: Aortic stenosis with exertional chest pain and syncope indicates severe stenosis. During exertion, cardiac output cannot increase due to the stenotic valve, causing inadequate coronary perfusion (chest pain) and cerebral hypoperfusion (syncope). This presents high risk for sudden cardiac death. The client needs urgent surgical evaluation for valve replacement.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with mitral regurgitation is at risk for which complication?
options: Hypercalcemia and bone disease
Atrial fibrillation and heart failure
Acute respiratory infections
Severe anemia and bleeding
questions.rationale: In mitral regurgitation, blood flows backward into the left atrium, causing atrial enlargement and dilation. This predisposes the client to atrial fibrillation (common complication). Over time, the increased volume load causes left ventricular dilation and eventually heart failure.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client is newly diagnosed with infective endocarditis. Which finding is most consistent with this diagnosis?
options: Fever, new or changing heart murmur, and embolic phenomena
Acute severe chest pain with ST-segment elevation
Gradual onset of dyspnea over months with orthopnea
Severe hypotension with cool extremities and poor perfusion
questions.rationale: The classic triad of endocarditis includes fever, new or changing murmur (from vegetation), and septic emboli (can cause skin lesions, splinter hemorrhages, Osler nodes). The condition develops over weeks to months. ST elevation is MI. Gradual dyspnea suggests heart failure. Poor perfusion suggests shock.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with infective endocarditis is on intravenous antibiotics. What nursing assessment is critical during antibiotic therapy?
options: Monitor for adequate IV access and signs of phlebitis.
Assess for signs of septic emboli such as splinter hemorrhages or Osler nodes.
Monitor vital signs and assess for signs of infection resolution.
All of the above are critical assessments.
questions.rationale: All are essential. IV access must be secure (risk of line infection), signs of ongoing septic emboli must be monitored, and vital signs and signs of clinical improvement with antibiotic therapy must be assessed. Long-term IV antibiotics (4-6 weeks) require diligent monitoring.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with pericarditis is experiencing chest pain worse with deep breathing and lying back. How would the nurse differentiate this pain from acute MI?
options: Pericardial pain radiates to the left arm and jaw.
Pericardial pain is relieved by sitting forward and NSAIDs.
Pericardial pain presents with ST-segment elevation in all leads.
Pericardial pain is associated with troponin elevation.
questions.rationale: Pericarditic chest pain is pleuritic (worse with deep breathing and lying back) and is relieved by sitting forward and NSAIDs. MI pain is substernal, radiates typically to the left arm, and is not relieved by NSAIDs. While pericarditis can have ST changes, they're typically diffuse (not localized) and troponin is normal.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client develops cardiac tamponade from pericardial effusion. What clinical finding would be most concerning?
options: Low-grade fever and mild chest discomfort
Muffled heart sounds, elevated JVP, and hypotension (Beck's triad)
Mild dyspnea with clear lung sounds
Tachycardia with no other symptoms
questions.rationale: Beck's triad of cardiac tamponade includes muffled heart sounds, elevated JVP, and hypotension. This represents life-threatening decreased cardiac output from pericardial fluid compressing the heart. The client requires emergency pericardiocentesis.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) should avoid which activity to prevent sudden cardiac death?
options: Competitive sports and intense physical exertion
Light walking and stretching
Swimming in a supervised setting
Watching television and reading
questions.rationale: HCM predisposes to sudden cardiac death, especially with intense exertion when the hypertrophied interventricular septum obstructs left ventricular outflow. Clients should avoid competitive sports and strenuous activities. Light activity is appropriate. Many HCM clients benefit from an ICD for sudden death prevention.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with dilated cardiomyopathy presents with dyspnea, orthopnea, and severe peripheral edema. What is the primary pathophysiology?
options: Narrowing of the coronary arteries decreasing blood flow.
Decreased cardiac contractility leading to increased preload and congestion.
Thickening of the ventricular wall preventing filling.
Acute inflammation of the myocardium.
questions.rationale: Dilated cardiomyopathy involves enlargement of the ventricles with decreased contractility. The weakened heart cannot empty adequately, leading to increased diastolic pressure and volume, which backs up into the lungs (pulmonary edema, orthopnea) and systemic circulation (peripheral edema).

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client recovering from acute coronary syndrome has been started on beta-blocker therapy. What is the primary benefit of beta-blockers post-MI?
options: Increasing heart rate to improve cardiac output.
Decreasing myocardial oxygen demand and heart rate, reducing ischemic events.
Dilating coronary vessels to improve blood flow.
Increasing blood pressure to maintain perfusion.
questions.rationale: Beta-blockers reduce heart rate, contractility, and blood pressure, which collectively decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This provides cardioprotection in post-MI patients, reducing future ischemic events and arrhythmias. Beta-blockers are a cornerstone of post-MI therapy.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client is scheduled for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. The nurse is providing pre-operative education. Which information is most important?
options: The surgery will completely cure coronary artery disease.
Grafts typically last 10-15 years for venous grafts and longer for arterial grafts.
The client will never need cardiac medications after successful surgery.
Physical activity must be permanently restricted after CABG.
questions.rationale: CABG provides symptom relief and improved survival but does not cure CAD. Venous grafts (saphenous vein) have limited longevity (10-15 years) due to atherosclerosis. Arterial grafts (internal mammary artery) last longer. Medications are typically continued post-operatively. Activity is gradually increased, not permanently restricted.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client has a new permanent pacemaker implant and is being discharged with a cardiac output of 50%. What is the priority nursing education for this client?
options: How to take his pulse and when to contact the provider.
Dietary sodium restriction and daily weights.
Activity restrictions and avoidance of heavy lifting.
All of the above are priority education topics.
questions.rationale: With significant left ventricular dysfunction (50% EF), comprehensive education is essential: pulse monitoring for device function, dietary restrictions for heart failure management, activity restrictions for safety, and infection prevention around the incision site.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with acute heart failure has pulmonary edema and is on IV nitroglycerin, furosemide, and dobutamine. What assessment finding indicates the treatment is effective?
options: Heart rate increases from 95 to 110 bpm.
Blood pressure decreases from 160/95 to 120/80 mm Hg.
Lung crackles clear and oxygen saturation improves to 95%.
Diastolic blood pressure decreases to below 60 mm Hg.
questions.rationale: Clearing of crackles and improved oxygenation indicate reduction of pulmonary edema, which is the primary goal in acute HF. The combination of diuretics (reducing fluid), vasodilators (reducing afterload), and inotropes (improving contractility) should reduce congestion and improve oxygenation. A diastolic BP below 60 mm Hg would be too low and concerning.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with stable angina is prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin. What instructions should the nurse provide about using this medication?
options: Take the medication only when chest pain becomes severe.
Place one tablet under the tongue; if pain persists after 5 minutes, take another; seek emergency care if pain not relieved after 3 doses.
Take the medication daily as a preventive measure.
Swallow the tablet whole with water for rapid absorption.
questions.rationale: Sublingual nitroglycerin should be taken at the first sign of chest pain, not only when severe. The correct protocol is one tablet under the tongue, and if not relieved in 5 minutes, take another, up to 3 tablets. If pain persists after 3 tablets over 15 minutes, the client should seek emergency care (may indicate MI). The tablet should dissolve under the tongue, not be swallowed.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client is referred for cardiac transplantation. Which factor is most important in determining transplant candidacy?
options: Client's age (must be under 50 years)
Severe heart failure refractory to medical therapy and good psychosocial support/compliance
Presence of peripheral vascular disease
History of previous cardiac procedures
questions.rationale: Transplant candidacy requires severe, medically refractory heart failure (cannot be managed with current therapies) and excellent psychosocial factors including compliance, no active substance abuse, and strong support system. Age is a relative, not absolute, contraindication. Other conditions are evaluated individually.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client with chronic heart failure is prescribed a beta-blocker and an ACE inhibitor. Why is this combination especially beneficial?
options: They work synergistically to slow the progression of heart failure.
They eliminate the need for other cardiac medications.
They increase sodium retention and improve fluid balance.
They directly improve cardiac contractility and systolic function.
questions.rationale: Beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors work synergistically: ACE inhibitors reduce afterload and prevent remodeling, while beta-blockers reduce heart rate, contractility, and oxygen demand. Together they slow HF progression, reduce hospitalizations, and improve survival. This combination is standard therapy.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Concepts of Care for Patients With Cardiac Conditions
questions.stem: A client recovering from a myocardial infarction is being discharged. Which recommendation would the nurse NOT include in discharge teaching?
options: Return to work gradually over several weeks.
Resume sexual activity when medically cleared.
Return to competitive sports within 2 weeks.
Participate in supervised cardiac rehabilitation.
questions.rationale: Returning to competitive sports within 2 weeks post-MI is inappropriate and dangerous. The client should gradually return to work over weeks, resume sexual activity when cleared (usually 2-4 weeks), and participate in cardiac rehabilitation. Activity should be gradually progressive under medical guidance.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Concepts of Care for Patients With Vascular Conditions
questions.stem: A client presents with acute arterial insufficiency in the left leg. Which assessment finding would the nurse expect?
options: Gradual onset of claudication with rest pain developing over months
Sudden onset of pain, pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis (6 Ps)
Gradual venous insufficiency with edema and skin discoloration
Cool extremity with mottled appearance and slow capillary refill
questions.rationale: Acute arterial insufficiency presents with the classic 6 Ps: pain (sudden), pallor, pulselessness, paresthesia, and paralysis. This is a vascular emergency requiring immediate intervention to prevent limb loss. The other descriptions fit chronic insufficiency or other conditions.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Concepts of Care for Patients With Vascular Conditions
questions.stem: A client with a blood pressure of 180/110 mm Hg is experiencing a hypertensive emergency with confusion, headache, and visual changes. What is the immediate priority?
options: Administer a single high dose of antihypertensive medication.
Have the client rest in a dark room without medications.
Reduce blood pressure by 10-15% over the first hour with IV medications.
Start oral antihypertensive medications and monitor for response.
questions.rationale: In hypertensive emergency with end-organ damage (confusion, visual changes), the goal is careful, gradual reduction of blood pressure by 10-15% over the first hour, then slower reduction. Abrupt reduction can cause stroke or organ damage. IV medications (nitroprusside, nitroglycerin, labetalol) are used for tight control.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Concepts of Care for Patients With Vascular Conditions
questions.stem: A client with chronic venous insufficiency is experiencing significant pain and swelling in the legs. What is the most effective non-pharmacologic intervention?
options: Elevating the legs above the heart for extended periods
Applying warm heat to the affected areas
Wearing graduated compression stockings and using leg elevation and exercise
Keeping the legs in a dependent position to promote blood flow
questions.rationale: The "3 Es" of venous insufficiency management are elastic compression stockings, exercise (walking), and elevation. Compression stockings provide external support, walking promotes calf muscle pumping, and elevation reduces hydrostatic pressure. These combined interventions are the most effective non-pharmacologic treatment.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Concepts of Care for Patients With Vascular Conditions
questions.stem: A client with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right leg is started on heparin therapy. What precaution is most important during the first 24 hours?
options: Encourage early ambulation to prevent extension of the clot.
Maintain bed rest with leg elevation and apply ice.
Start anticoagulation and monitor for signs of pulmonary embolism.
Perform vigorous leg massage to improve circulation.
questions.rationale: While anticoagulation is started, the critical precaution is monitoring for pulmonary embolism (PE), which can occur as a thrombus dislodges. Bed rest is typically prescribed initially. Massage is contraindicated as it can dislodge the clot. Early ambulation is introduced gradually as the clot stabilizes.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Concepts of Care for Patients With Vascular Conditions
questions.stem: A client is diagnosed with severe peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and experiences intermittent claudication. What medication would provide symptomatic relief?
options: Aspirin for its antiplatelet effects
Cilostazol or pentoxifylline for improved blood flow
Nitroglycerin for vasodilation
Beta-blockers to reduce heart rate
questions.rationale: Cilostazol and pentoxifylline improve walking distance and reduce claudication symptoms by enhancing blood flow and reducing blood viscosity. Aspirin provides antiplatelet benefits but doesn't reduce claudication. Nitroglycerin and beta-blockers don't target claudication specifically.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Concepts of Care for Patients With Vascular Conditions
questions.stem: A client with critical limb ischemia is being evaluated for vascular intervention. Which finding indicates the need for urgent intervention?
options: Claudication with normal ankle-brachial index
Rest pain, tissue loss, and severe limiting claudication
Mild edema with intact skin
Cool extremity but intact sensation and color
questions.rationale: Critical limb ischemia includes rest pain, tissue ulceration or gangrene, and severely limiting claudication. These findings indicate imminent threat of limb loss and require urgent revascularization (bypass, angioplasty, or amputation). The other findings are less severe.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Concepts of Care for Patients With Vascular Conditions
questions.stem: A client recovering from abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair is being discharged home. Which assessment would be most concerning post-operatively?
options: Mild incisional pain controlled with medications
Pulsatile abdominal mass that has enlarged since discharge
Slight fever on the first post-operative day
Mild lower extremity edema
questions.rationale: An enlarging pulsatile abdominal mass post-AAA repair could indicate anastomotic leak or expansion of the repair, which is a surgical emergency. The client should be instructed to report any new pulsatile mass or abdominal changes immediately. Mild post-operative pain and fever are expected.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Concepts of Care for Patients With Vascular Conditions
questions.stem: A client with Raynaud's phenomenon is experiencing severe vasospastic attacks. What teaching would be most helpful?
